Have won his grace to come in person hither
And take perforce my husband from the Abbess .

sp.speaker: SECOND MERCHANT
sp.l: By this , I think , the dial points at five .
Anon , I’m sure , the Duke himself in person
Comes this way to the melancholy vale ,
The place of death and sorry execution
Behind the ditches of the abbey here .

sp.speaker: ANGELO
sp.l: Upon what cause ?

sp.speaker: SECOND MERCHANT
sp.l: To see a reverend Syracusian merchant ,
Who put unluckily into this bay
Against the laws and statutes of this town ,
Beheaded publicly for his offense .

sp.speaker: ANGELO
sp.l: See where they come . We will behold his death .

sp.speaker: LUCIANA , to Adriana
sp.l: Kneel to the Duke before he pass the abbey .

stage.hi: Enter the Duke of Ephesus , and Egeon the Merchant of Syracuse , bare head , with the Headsman and other Officers .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Yet once again proclaim it publicly ,
If any friend will pay the sum for him ,
He shall not die ; so much we tender him .

sp.speaker: ADRIANA , kneeling
sp.l: Justice , most sacred duke , against the Abbess .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: She is a virtuous and a reverend lady .
It cannot be that she hath done thee wrong .

sp.speaker: ADRIANA
sp.l: May it please your Grace , Antipholus my husband ,
Who I made lord of me and all I had
At your important letters , this ill day
A most outrageous fit of madness took him ,
That desp’rately he hurried through the street ,
With him his bondman , all as mad as he ,
Doing displeasure to the citizens
By rushing in their houses , bearing thence
Rings , jewels , anything his rage did like .
Once did I get him bound and sent him home
Whilst to take order for the wrongs I went
That here and there his fury had committed .
Anon , I wot not by what strong escape ,
He broke from those that had the guard of him ,
And with his mad attendant and himself ,
Each one with ireful passion , with drawn swords ,
Met us again and , madly bent on us ,
Chased us away , till raising of more aid ,
We came again to bind them . Then they fled
Into this abbey , whither we pursued them ,
And here the Abbess shuts the gates on us
And will not suffer us to fetch him out ,
Nor send him forth that we may bear him hence .
Therefore , most gracious duke , with thy command
Let him be brought forth and borne hence for help .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Long since , thy husband served me in my wars ,
And I to thee engaged a prince’s word ,
When thou didst make him master of thy bed ,
To do him all the grace and good I could .
Go , some of you , knock at the abbey gate ,
And bid the Lady Abbess come to me .
I will determine this before I stir .

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: O mistress , mistress , shift and save yourself .
My master and his man are both broke loose ,
Beaten the maids a-row , and bound the doctor ,
Whose beard they have singed off with brands of fire ,
And ever as it blazed they threw on him
Great pails of puddled mire to quench the hair .
My master preaches patience to him , and the while
His man with scissors nicks him like a fool ;
And sure , unless you send some present help ,
Between them they will kill the conjurer .

sp.speaker: ADRIANA
sp.l: Peace , fool . Thy master and his man are here ,
And that is false thou dost report to us .

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Mistress , upon my life I tell you true .
I have not breathed almost since I did see it .
He cries for you and vows , if he can take you ,
To scorch your face and to disfigure you .
Hark , hark , I hear him , mistress . Fly , begone !

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Come , stand by me . Fear nothing . — Guard with halberds .

stage.hi: Enter Antipholus and Dromio of Ephesus .

sp.speaker: ADRIANA
sp.l: Ay me , it is my husband . Witness you
That he is borne about invisible .
Even now we housed him in the abbey here ,
And now he’s there , past thought of human reason .

sp.speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
sp.l: Justice , most gracious duke . O , grant me justice ,
Even for the service that long since I did thee
When I bestrid thee in the wars and took
Deep scars to save thy life . Even for the blood
That then I lost for thee , now grant me justice .

sp.speaker: EGEON , aside
sp.l: Unless the fear of death doth make me dote ,
I see my son Antipholus and Dromio .

sp.speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
sp.l: Justice , sweet prince , against that woman there ,
She whom thou gav’st to me to be my wife ,
That hath abusèd and dishonored me
Even in the strength and height of injury .
Beyond imagination is the wrong
That she this day hath shameless thrown on me .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Discover how , and thou shalt find me just .

sp.speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
sp.l: This day , great duke , she shut the doors upon me
While she with harlots feasted in my house .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: A grievous fault . — Say , woman , didst thou so ?

sp.speaker: ADRIANA
sp.l: No , my good lord . Myself , he , and my sister
Today did dine together . So befall my soul
As this is false he burdens me withal .

sp.speaker: LUCIANA
sp.l: Ne’er may I look on day nor sleep on night
But she tells to your Highness simple truth .

sp.speaker: ANGELO
sp.l: O perjured woman ! — They are both forsworn .
In this the madman justly chargeth them .

sp.speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
sp.l: My liege , I am advisèd what I say ,
Neither disturbed with the effect of wine ,
Nor heady-rash provoked with raging ire ,
Albeit my wrongs might make one wiser mad .
This woman locked me out this day from dinner .
That goldsmith there , were he not packed with her ,
Could witness it , for he was with me then ,
Who parted with me to go fetch a chain ,
Promising to bring it to the Porpentine ,
Where Balthasar and I did dine together .
Our dinner done and he not coming thither ,
I went to seek him . In the street I met him ,
And in his company that gentleman .
There did this perjured goldsmith swear me down
That I this day of him received the chain ,
Which , God He knows , I saw not ; for the which
He did arrest me with an officer .
I did obey and sent my peasant home
For certain ducats . He with none returned .
Then fairly I bespoke the officer
To go in person with me to my house .
By th’ way we met
My wife , her sister , and a rabble more
Of vile confederates . Along with them
They brought one Pinch , a hungry , lean-faced villain ,
A mere anatomy , a mountebank ,
A threadbare juggler , and a fortune-teller ,
A needy , hollow-eyed , sharp-looking wretch ,
A living dead man . This pernicious slave ,
Forsooth , took on him as a conjurer ,
And , gazing in mine eyes , feeling my pulse ,
And with no face ( as ’twere ) outfacing me ,
Cries out I was possessed . Then all together
They fell upon me , bound me , bore me thence ,
And in a dark and dankish vault at home
There left me and my man , both bound together ,
Till gnawing with my teeth my bonds in sunder ,
I gained my freedom and immediately
Ran hither to your Grace , whom I beseech
To give me ample satisfaction
For these deep shames and great indignities .

sp.speaker: ANGELO
sp.l: My lord , in truth , thus far I witness with him :
That he dined not at home , but was locked out .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: But had he such a chain of thee or no ?

sp.speaker: ANGELO
sp.l: He had , my lord , and when he ran in here ,
These people saw the chain about his neck .

sp.speaker: SECOND MERCHANT , to Antipholus of Ephesus
sp.l: Besides , I will be sworn these ears of mine
Heard you confess you had the chain of him
After you first forswore it on the mart ,
And thereupon I drew my sword on you ,
And then you fled into this abbey here ,
From whence I think you are come by miracle .

sp.speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
sp.l: I never came within these abbey walls ,
Nor ever didst thou draw thy sword on me .
I never saw the chain , so help me heaven ,
And this is false you burden me withal .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Why , what an intricate impeach is this !
I think you all have drunk of Circe’s cup .
If here you housed him , here he would have been .
If he were mad , he would not plead so coldly .
You say he dined at home ; the goldsmith here
Denies that saying .
Sirrah , what say you ?

sp.speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS , pointing to the Courtesan
sp.l: Sir , he dined with her there at the Porpentine .

sp.speaker: COURTESAN
sp.l: He did , and from my finger snatched that ring .

sp.speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS , showing a ring
sp.l: ’Tis true , my liege , this ring I had of her .

sp.speaker: DUKE , to Courtesan
sp.l: Saw’st thou him enter at the abbey here ?

sp.speaker: COURTESAN
sp.l: As sure , my liege , as I do see your Grace .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Why , this is strange . — Go call the Abbess hither .
I think you are all mated or stark mad .

sp.speaker: EGEON
sp.l: Most mighty duke , vouchsafe me speak a word .
Haply I see a friend will save my life
And pay the sum that may deliver me .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Speak freely , Syracusian , what thou wilt .

sp.speaker: EGEON , to Antipholus of Ephesus
sp.l: Is not your name , sir , called Antipholus ?
And is not that your bondman Dromio ?

sp.speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
sp.l: Within this hour I was his bondman , sir ,
But he , I thank him , gnawed in two my cords .
Now am I Dromio , and his man , unbound .

sp.speaker: EGEON
sp.l: I am sure you both of you remember me .

sp.speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
sp.l: Ourselves we do remember , sir , by you ,
For lately we were bound as you are now .
You are not Pinch’s patient , are you , sir ?

sp.speaker: EGEON , to Antipholus of Ephesus
sp.l: Why look you strange on me ? You know me well .

sp.speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
sp.l: I never saw you in my life till now .

sp.speaker: EGEON
sp.l: O , grief hath changed me since you saw me last ,
And careful hours with time’s deformèd hand
Have written strange defeatures in my face .
But tell me yet , dost thou not know my voice ?

p.l: Neither .
Dromio , nor thou ?
No , trust me , sir , nor I .
I am sure thou dost .
Ay , sir , but I am sure I do not , and
whatsoever a man denies , you are now bound to
believe him .

sp.speaker: EGEON
sp.l: Not know my voice ! O time’s extremity ,
Hast thou so cracked and splitted my poor tongue
In seven short years that here my only son
Knows not my feeble key of untuned cares ?
Though now this grainèd face of mine be hid
In sap-consuming winter’s drizzled snow ,
And all the conduits of my blood froze up ,
Yet hath my night of life some memory ,
My wasting lamps some fading glimmer left ,
My dull deaf ears a little use to hear .
All these old witnesses — I cannot err —
Tell me thou art my son Antipholus .

sp.speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
sp.l: I never saw my father in my life .

sp.speaker: EGEON
sp.l: But seven years since , in Syracusa , boy ,
Thou know’st we parted . But perhaps , my son ,
Thou sham’st to acknowledge me in misery .

sp.speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
sp.l: The Duke and all that know me in the city
Can witness with me that it is not so .
I ne’er saw Syracusa in my life .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: I tell thee , Syracusian , twenty years
Have I been patron to Antipholus ,
During which time he ne’er saw Syracusa .
I see thy age and dangers make thee dote .

stage.hi: Enter Emilia the Abbess , with Antipholus of Syracuse and Dromio of Syracuse .

sp.speaker: ABBESS
sp.l: Most mighty duke , behold a man much wronged .

sp.speaker: ADRIANA
sp.l: I see two husbands , or mine eyes deceive me .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: One of these men is genius to the other .
And so , of these , which is the natural man
And which the spirit ? Who deciphers them ?

sp.speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
sp.l: I , sir , am Dromio . Command him away .

sp.speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
sp.l: I , sir , am Dromio . Pray , let me stay .

sp.speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
sp.l: Egeon art thou not , or else his ghost ?

sp.speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
sp.l: O , my old master . — Who hath bound him here ?

sp.speaker: ABBESS
sp.l: Whoever bound him , I will loose his bonds
And gain a husband by his liberty . —
Speak , old Egeon , if thou be’st the man
That hadst a wife once called Emilia ,
That bore thee at a burden two fair sons .
O , if thou be’st the same Egeon , speak ,
And speak unto the same Emilia .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Why , here begins his morning story right :
These two Antipholus’ , these two so like ,
And these two Dromios , one in semblance —
Besides her urging of her wrack at sea —
These are the parents to these children ,
Which accidentally are met together .

sp.speaker: EGEON
sp.l: If I dream not , thou art Emilia .
If thou art she , tell me , where is that son
That floated with thee on the fatal raft ?

sp.speaker: ABBESS
sp.l: By men of Epidamium he and I
And the twin Dromio all were taken up ;
But by and by rude fishermen of Corinth
By force took Dromio and my son from them ,
And me they left with those of Epidamium .
What then became of them I cannot tell ;
I to this fortune that you see me in .

sp.speaker: DUKE , to Antipholus of Syracuse
sp.l: Antipholus , thou cam’st from Corinth first .

sp.speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
sp.l: No , sir , not I . I came from Syracuse .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: Stay , stand apart . I know not which is which .

sp.speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
sp.l: I came from Corinth , my most gracious lord .

sp.speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
sp.l: And I with him .

sp.speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
sp.l: Brought to this town by that most famous warrior
Duke Menaphon , your most renownèd uncle .

sp.speaker: ADRIANA
sp.l: Which of you two did dine with me today ?

sp.speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
sp.l: I , gentle mistress .

sp.speaker: ADRIANA
sp.l: And are not you my husband ?

sp.speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
sp.l: No , I say nay to that .

sp.speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
sp.l: And so do I , yet did she call me so ,
And this fair gentlewoman , her sister here ,
Did call me brother . To Luciana . What I told you then
I hope I shall have leisure to make good ,
If this be not a dream I see and hear .

sp.speaker: ANGELO , turning to Antipholus of Syracuse
sp.l: That is the chain , sir , which you had of me .

sp.speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE
sp.l: I think it be , sir . I deny it not .

sp.speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS , to Angelo
sp.l: And you , sir , for this chain arrested me .

sp.speaker: ANGELO
sp.l: I think I did , sir . I deny it not .

sp.speaker: ADRIANA , to Antipholus of Ephesus
sp.l: I sent you money , sir , to be your bail
By Dromio , but I think he brought it not .

sp.speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
sp.l: No , none by me .

sp.speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE , to Adriana
sp.l: This purse of ducats I received from you ,
And Dromio my man did bring them me .
I see we still did meet each other’s man ,
And I was ta’en for him , and he for me ,
And thereupon these errors are arose .

sp.speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS , to the Duke
sp.l: These ducats pawn I for my father here .

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: It shall not need . Thy father hath his life .

sp.speaker: COURTESAN , to Antipholus of Ephesus
sp.l: Sir , I must have that diamond from you .

sp.speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
sp.l: There , take it , and much thanks for my good cheer .

sp.speaker: ABBESS
sp.l: Renownèd duke , vouchsafe to take the pains
To go with us into the abbey here
And hear at large discoursèd all our fortunes ,
And all that are assembled in this place
That by this sympathizèd one day’s error
Have suffered wrong . Go , keep us company ,
And we shall make full satisfaction . —
Thirty-three years have I but gone in travail
Of you , my sons , and till this present hour
My heavy burden ne’er deliverèd . —
The Duke , my husband , and my children both ,
And you , the calendars of their nativity ,
Go to a gossips’ feast , and go with me .
After so long grief , such nativity !

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.l: With all my heart I’ll gossip at this feast .

stage.hi: All exit except the two Dromios and the two brothers Antipholus .

sp.speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE , to Antipholus of Ephesus
sp.l: Master , shall I fetch your stuff from shipboard ?

sp.speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF EPHESUS
sp.l: Dromio , what stuff of mine hast thou embarked ?

sp.speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
sp.l: Your goods that lay at host , sir , in the Centaur .

sp.speaker: ANTIPHOLUS OF SYRACUSE , to Antipholus of Ephesus
sp.l: He speaks to me . — I am your master , Dromio .
Come , go with us . We’ll look to that anon .
Embrace thy brother there . Rejoice with him .

sp.speaker: DROMIO OF SYRACUSE
sp.l: There is a fat friend at your master’s house
That kitchened me for you today at dinner .
She now shall be my sister , not my wife .

sp.speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
sp.l: Methinks you are my glass , and not my brother .
I see by you I am a sweet-faced youth .
Will you walk in to see their gossiping ?

p.l: Not I , sir . You are my elder .
That’s a question . How shall we
try it ?
We’ll draw cuts for the signior .
Till then , lead thou first .

sp.speaker: DROMIO OF EPHESUS
sp.l: Nay , then , thus :
We came into the world like brother and brother ,
And now let’s go hand in hand , not one before another .
